instruction: Can the proposed deep learning system trained on heart rate signals derived from functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (fNIRS) be considered superior to traditional methods in stress classification?
Output: Yes. The proposed deep learning system trained on heart rate signals derived from functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (fNIRS) can be considered superior to traditional methods in stress classification. The results of the related study showed that the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) approach outperformed other methods such as the Dense Neural Network, Support Vector Machine, and Random Forest in terms of stress classification metrics. The trained model achieved a higher accuracy of 98.69 +/- 0.45% compared to other models. Additionally, the proposed method demonstrated better stability with lower variation in prediction and had a lower computational cost, making it suitable for real-time monitoring of stress assessment.
